column4: Where do you manually install things in Ubuntu? Ie, Blender, GoogleAppEngine server, etc?
Depends on the program. If it's in a repository, use Synaptic...if it's source code, gotta compile it. if it's a deb package, gotta download it, open it and install it
thanks ;)
So, what if its none of those 3?
Could you be more specific? What format IS it in?
Blender comes as a .. tar, heh. No installer of any form, it runs out of the directory you unzip it to.
And the google app i'm talking about seems to be similar, except its specifically having to do with python.
Well i mean, so there is no .. standard? Ubuntu just wants you to shove crap where ever? Seems odd. heh

For a program to support to Ubuntu "standard"....it has to be packaged as a *deb file, or a deb file in a repository. that's the purpose of the deb file, is to tell everything where to get stored, so that it does it the "ubuntu-way"
Yea, but im asking how do _i_ do it the "ubuntu way" :o
Well, im not wondering how to install.. i just figured there was a standard where most programs sat. If not, i can make my own, no biggie.

Yea. Heh, i mean.. I've got my blender directory sitting in "/usr/local/" which just seems.. odd. Yet i was told to. Though there seems to be no reason why, since i just created a symlink to a dif spot anyway.. its just hacky.. heh
Yea i know, thats why im asking for this simple case of "where to shove crap" heh
I don't like the feel of "shoving crap" in /usr/local/
I know, i just wanted to shove it where it belonged haha. Guess they dont really belong anywhere heh
Sounds good, thank you
i'd abandon both and just use synaptic..but unop will probably chime in and dissagree  :P
That doesn't help me over ssh heh
I didnt, but then again i didnt mention anything about a 3rd option. ;P
So if you wanna get technical, hehe
